title: Female Action Figure 38 Points of Articulation

description.text:
I present to you a 3D printed female action figure / pose reference tool. I Learned a ton from the male 70 points of articulation action figure I made. This time I wanted balance and range of motion to be the key focus. Much research went into the type of joints on action figures vs what could be possible in a 3D print .
http://thecollectionary.com/club/action-figures See image of the model balancing on one foot.
It has a interchangeable hand system, Making this thing a very useful tool in the hands of an artist. (fact, teachers love puns)
I included a large variation of hands to choose from that quickly mount into place using a PLA spike.
If the breasts are too big I have included a smaller size. The whole character is set to classic heroine body type standards. 8 heads flat feet tall so don't be shocked when you get her printed out.. Just find a spear mount it in her hands and you have a amazon warrior for your desk or studio. Also included the blender file in case you want to develop for the model or make new hands

For instructions on assembly see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116571
It has some breakdowns of this model type. I have upgraded the ball joints so there is no friction collar to deal with. Print the hands with support Development Diary video located here
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DFZyPCRCmd4&feature=c4-overview&list=UUyMH4WpbXjgSp0qfh6BjckA

comments.text: I may come back to this project when I have a little more experience.  As a beginner, using Cura, I found the multiple parts in single file pretty much impossible to deal with.  I can separate the pieces once they are imported in to Cura, but keeping track of what got printed seemed too complex, without more faith that I would encounter more difficulties as the project progressed. It would help to have mention, somewhere, of the overall size of the figure, beyond "8 heads".  I think next time I download from Thingverse I will hold off on the tip until I have a look at the files, lol...  I make windup sculptures and this figure would look great turned into a windup.  My intention was to incorporate a lot of metal parts both for the function and the look.

description.text: Ideal for Trout Area Game of Fly Fishing. Set your spoon or small hard/softbaits in this box. Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:386904. Use the "Open in Customizer" button to create one in any size you want.

Waterblock holder for 1155 CPU
Background: I updated my PC from a core2duo to corei7.
Since my computer is watercooled, I had to replace the CPU waterblock holder.
The waterblock comes from a german company called: innovatek.de
For my bad (or good luck) there was no holder for a 1155 cpu available.
Solution: Make one.
The pictures will tell the hole story.
The Design was made with Design Spark Mechanical an can be simple modified to your need.
The "smart" part is how to assebly it and how to maintain the required pressure on the CPU.
The entire thing from thinking to have it in the PC: ~3 hours (including prining).
Enjoy makeing your own.
Marko

This servo saver is designed to protect the gears inside of a servo by twisting or breaking in the event of a large shock. These are commonly used on RC vehicles and robots that experience rough environments.
Each arm features 1.5mm diameter holes and should be compatible with most linkages. I have also created a version with 3mm holes if needed.
I DO NOT guarantee or warranty the effectiveness of this device in protecting your servos. Use with caution.
If you like this project or want to know more about 3D printing, check out my new book "The Makerspace Workbench" from Maker Media!

description.text:
I recently got hold of a Wanhao i3 v1 printer, and when I upgraded it with a Glass plate on the printbed, I needed to correct the Z-axis. It seems the normal way to do this is to physically move the Z-axis endswitch. That's too much work for me, so I designed this clip. It should fit snugly onto the metal frame right above the switch and add about 4mm of offset.
No drilling, no screwing.
There really shouldn't be any critical settings for printing.
Just trim the edges with a knife in case they've been 'squished out' a bit.

I needed a mount for a brushless motor on one of my small 'foamie' RC planes so designed this. It works very well. Note that it is designed for motors with 18mm and 16mm bolt spacing. The wide mounting holes on the bracket allow it to be angled to incorporate down- or right thrust simply by adding spacers behind the mount. This was designed for a small GWS Corsair model and has been reliable and is showing no signs of problems despite being asked to mount the motor of more than 160W! The Interface Board http://store.makerbot.com/makerbot-interface-board-kit-v1-1.html for the TOM should computer-less operation. Printing works well from an SD card, but the current TOM firmware does not include extruder support from the Interface Board so you still needed the ReplicatorG control panel to change filament before a build. This script solves that problem.

Preparation
Open the f_change.gcode file in ReplicatorG and Build To File, saving the s3g file on the SD card. Changing Filament
  • Loosen the filament drive tension screw.
  • Run the f_change.s3g file from the Interface Board.
  • When the Tool temp gets to 220C pull the old filament from the extruder and insert the new filament until it starts to extrude.
  • When the extruder starts running, tighten the tension screw as you normally do.
  • Allow the extruder to run until the new color is coming out correctly, then cancel the build. I have found that going to a darker color only takes a couple of minutes, but going from a darker color to a light color can take up to 5 minutes. The script is set to run for up to 5 minutes.

author: adreas25

description.text:
I built zgbot's air filter for my Thing-o-Matic during the machine's build process. I made it to sit on top of the machine, but after about 6 months of being moved around the duct tape started to come loose. Between that and a circular saw I hadn't had a chance to use I decided to make a version out of plywood.
It takes a square cabin air filter about 8"x.75"x1", which I believe is used on Toyota and Lexus cars such as the RX 350. I'm not really sure because I just bought one from an auto parts store that looked like I could build something around it and I never really paid attention. The filter I bought has activated carbon in it to help with the smell. 
The air filter goes in the top, and sits on the edges of the bottom half. It's actually a big pain to get in there so if I had it to do over, I'd make one of the side panels on the top section come off (instead of the lid) and slip the filter in that way.
There are 2 80mm fans on top, which make a little more noise (and push more air) than I'd like. The next time I'm doing some internal work, I intend to move them from 12v to 7v so they'll slow down. I've got a simple switch on the line so I can turn them on and off, and I used a barrel plug from RadioShack so I can disconnect the filter and remove it.
The top is a little short, just enough to be able to hang the LCD controls off the front of the machine. The back of the filter sits on the back lip of the ToM. This way I didn't have to put a cutout in for the Z motor. On the sides, I sanded out little channels to be able to fit over the M3 bolts on the top of the machine. 
The base section is 3" tall, which was just enough so that the filament drive wouldn't hit the bottom of the filter when at max Z. With the new MK7s, it looks like it could be reduced almost all the way. As it is though, there would be enough room on the front panel of the base section to embed an LCD and control pad, which could look pretty neat.
All measurements are in inches (because I don't seem to own a metric ruler or tape measure), and should more or less correspond with what I built. It's designed for 1/4" plywood. The panels are secured together with brads through the ends (into holes I pre-drilled with a 1/32" or 1/64" bit), and I glued and nailed some 3/4" wood strips in the corners to provide extra support. The top lid is simply screwed on into tapped holes in the extra wood strips. I believe, all together, I used less than half a sheet of plywood. 
I've been using it for a few weeks now, and it works quite well. Having the filament feed straight through the top has worked out quite well. It requires punching a hole in the air filter, but it means that it can drop straight down into the extruder.
Cut out, assemble, enjoy.

comments.text: nice work!  does the normal air filter work ok?  the one i used was activated carbon that removes odors and who knows what else.  that one looks WAY better than the one that i slapped together.
comments.author: zgbot

comments.text: Thanks. I thought yours looked pretty good, but then again I got to see my original. I didn't actually measure when building it, and had to stick little cardboard legs on it when I realized it was too short. These tended to fall off (I should have used glue), so it would occasionally fall off the machine. That only lead to further failure. This was my first woodworking project, and I learned quite a bit.
comments.author: zgbot

I did not create or scan this 3d model, I just made it better. I really liked this 3d scan, but it was really lacking in the detail department. I re-sculpted portions of the model and added some definition. I did not spend a lot of time on it and I would have liked to add a crossbow as a weapon he could hold in his hand, but maybe I'll work on it later. This is not a working bobblehead! The original creator of this 3d model is Michael Goyette or MadMyk. You can view the original source file at the link below: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:174282 UPDATE: I chopped the model up into two pieces for easy printing, use supports just in case. I did it all for the Wookie!

title: Sega Net City Arcade Cabinet Bolt Cover

description.text:
This print is for a replacement bolt/screw cover on a Sega Net City or Naomi Universal arcade machine. If you've done work on these machines you'll know these covers have a tendency to break or get lost.
The non-critical internal dimensions aren't perfect but the external dimension seem to fit my machine perfectly.  Pictures compare it to an original bolt cover and installed on a machine.

Printer:

Rigidbot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes: I designed the flat "decorative" side the model a hair undersized so that on a heated bed the elephant foot effect would bring it to it's desired final dimensions. Similarly, I recommend printing on a heated smooth surface such as glass aluminum, or kapton tape over so that the decorative side comes out smooth to match the smooth surface of the cabinet. This is the best side to use for printing as well. I used supports from build platform to help keep the clip from sagging, the angle of the major overhang is such that it didn't need support.

title: Minimal Spray Coolant upgrade for BZT CNC mill

description.text: (printed in PLA on Printrbot Simple Metal) I had a hairy experience recently while milling acrylic panels for a heated build chamber (See also http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:915401 ). So I upgraded the cooling system and haven't had any issues since. These parts will fasten a coolant bottle and Noga minimal spray sytem on BZT cnc mills. M4 threads and M4 locknuts tighten the parts against a complementary fasteners. The bottle fixture won't collide when milling near the machine limits (this isn't evident in the posted pictures). I'm using these parts to feed 2 Noga minimal spray systems. They are powered via 2 airbrush compressors, which are silent enough my neighbors still greet me kindly. The compressors need to be aircooled for continuous operation - that modification is posted here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1270978

title: led mount for motorcycle checklights invisible when fitted.

description.text:
this thing is to fit in fork pivot of motorcycles with a 17mm inner diameter pivot (can be easily adjusted for bigger).
it has seven lights in it.
lights will be seen only when blinking because of the thin layer of plastic in top of it. thread is custom profile with inf/45Â° angle shape
leds are this type for the size, aviable in different colors and brightness: http://datasheet.octopart.com/L-13GD-Kingbright-datasheet-640398.pdf
and each has its shape printed in the cap to fit perfectly
design allow to maintenance leds and resistors(let wires be long enough before filling the bottom chamber with silicon). i wonder if it can be 3d printed, because of the many details it has in a so close space, i have designed this to fit perfectly on my '86 honda 500vtc custom motorcycle project.
visible here:
http://www.customnetwork.fr/index.php?option=com_content&view=section&layout=blog&id=4&Itemid=29 but still not have access to a 3d printer, so if you are interessted in similar part for you an have the printer i can make mods to fit your bike if you could print this one for me. sounds like a good deal... UPDATE: after playing with replicatorg, i have found errors to make it printable on TOM so i update files for cleaner ones and one stl to make it in one build directly.
still can't print it, so please tell me if you do so.

print the 3 parts, assemble the leds on "support led" cut pint to 5mm height of the suppport, and wire it with the resistors needed for you. the wires goes out by the hole wich contain a chamber in "body" this chamber will be filled with silicon for water proofing. on the bike, wires pass through the pivot holes so, they are completely invisible.
the little mark hole just under the cap is to show the top side when you install it on the bike.
has never been printed yet, but designed to be well made on a thing o matic.

author: circulus

description.text:
I wanted to design a 3d printer using the tools I had which didn’t include a functioning 3d printer. I did have a twoup printer but I didn't have any success with print so I decided to reuse the mechanical and electronics and I have a cnc router. So almost everything can be cut on a cnc with common materials and for under $150 not including the salvaged parts.
The box frame is made of 1/2″ MDF. I’ve been told MDF isn’t a good material for the frame because wood can expand or contract but it does seem quite stable so far.
Gantry parts were originally MDF as well but I changed to a mix of 1/4 “HDPE for the carriage the hods the hot end and 1/2″ Corian for the X rails. I did have a laser cut part on the gantry that holds the belts and I used acrylic for that. The extruder is also made of HDPE. The Z platform is made of MDF. All the rails are 8mm and I use a total of 8 linear bearings.
My electronics consist of 4 NEMA 17 steppers motor, arduino Mega with Ramps, 4 polulu style steppers drivers and a 12v 5a power supply.
Sorry if I'm missing something I'll probably update it soon.

remixed_from.author: AndrewBCN
remixed_from.title: Ultimate Greg's Wade's Geared Extruder - 30mm version

description.text:
2016.02.06: Added the short_inductive version. This is designed to fit a 4mm inductive probe close, but not dangerously so, near the extruder. Be sure that you don't run your extruder wires near the sensor or you'll get some consistency issues.
2016.01.14: Uploaded the short version. Same extruder, same gears but I have reduced the filament path as much as possible so when the filament leaves the hobbed bolt, it travels 23mm before it hits your extruder. Any shorter and I'll have to redesign the guideler.
2016.01.13: Updated the latest version. I had uploaded the wrong rev which had the filament slot too small and not enough room for the guidler bearing. Sorry about that. NOTE: Filament tolerances are TIGHT on this extruder. If you are using cheap 1.75mm filament that is out of spec it might jam up. The tradeoff though is that flexible filament is a breeze. This is a geared wades extruder for 1.75mm filament that is designed to bolt directly to a piece of openbuilds 20mm v-slot extrusion. This started as a remix of the wades ultimate extruder, but I suck at OpenSCAD so I rebuilt the entire thing in 123d design (123d files attached) and went ham from there. You'll need some 25mm hex head screws and tnuts to mount this to your extrusion, hotends mount directly but I went ahead and left the jhead slot plate holes in case anyone needs that for accessories. This is for a custom printer I'm building from all openbuilds materials, ignore the busted hexagon hotend. It's just there for fitting.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

i3v

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3 or smaller

Infill:

10% or greater

Notes: I use PETG because it's awesome, but I tried to make as many of the surfaces round as possible to try to make ABS a bit more friendly of a print.

comments.text: Nice build, really like the design!!! I did similar upgrades using OB parts on my Folgertech 2020 printer...if interested you can check out my Y-Axis Upgrade here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1278055
comments.author: sonnylowe

comments.text: I like using PETG also.  Did you print the gears in PETG also?  How does the extruder hold up under the higher temps?  I have been using a X-Carriage printed in PETG for a week or so and has not shown any signs of heat problems even with 4+ hour prints.  I have been temped to print the extruder in PETG also and after seeing yours, maybe I will.
comments.author: GeoDave

comments.text: The gears I did in Nylon mostly because I had them already from the previous Wades extruder.  As for the PETG and temperature, I've had 0 issue with it. It's GlassT is 88 whereas ABS is 106, but even in an enclosure I've never gotten the temperatures that high.  What helps though is to make sure you use at least 30% infill so you have more mass that has to be heated.

Light Saber style hilt / handle & mold for an Iceblock / Icy Pole. To Do:
1) Design a longer lug to give ice more structural integrity.
2) Increase size of dowel holes to suit 1.75mm filament dowels.
3) Design an alternative that has the lug incorporated into one half of the handle.
4) Or even print the handle vertical in one piece to avoid the "small part chocking hazard.
5) Design a stand to hold multiple Ice Saber's vertical in the freezer.
6) Design a 2 part mold tube for easy release.
  • Updates:
    8-1-2013: Updated Tube stl

PRINTING: Print the Both Handle sections with the following settings: Infill 20%
Layer Height 0.2mm
Number of shells 2
Feedrate 40 mm/s
Travel Feedrate 80 mm/s
Print Temperature 230c Print the Tube & Lug with the following settings: Infill 100%
Layer Height 0.2mm
Number of shells 2
Feedrate 40 mm/s
Travel Feedrate 80 mm/s
Print Temperature 230c ASSEMBLY: 1) Use cyanoacrylate (super glue) to position the "Lug" into the recess in the "Lightsaber right" half of the handle. (you may need to trim the lug with an exacto knife for it to be a perfect fit.)
2) Make 3x dowels ~6mm (1/4") long out of wire or what ever you have laying around that will fit snug in the holes. I used stainless steel mig wire.
3) Super glue the dowels into position in one half of the handle.
4) Generously super glue the 2 halves of the handle together & evenly clamp until gule is set. USE: 1) Mix up some cordial in a jug that can pour.
2) Pour cordial into the tube to the top.
3) Mom voice "over the sink!" push the handle lug first into the cordial filled tube until it pops into posItion. Don't worry if there is a small gap of no codial at the top as it will expand as it freezes.
4) Stand vertical (blade down) in freezer until set.
5) Run warm water evenly over tube to help release your Ice Saber.
6) Om nom nom nom. Enjoy!

title: Demand feeder spout for small pellets

description.text: I'm trying to make a demand fish feeder around the core of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34100. This piece is untested as I left my filament in the office, but is meant to go on the end of the 2" PVC tee and prevent the small pellets from leaking out, while funnelling what the auger actively pushes out into a 3/4" poly tube which will direct them into the fishtank. Add a pull string attached to a momentary switch and some Arduino code, and hopefully my fish will be able to feed themselves throughout each day! Updated (2013/Aug/29): the first version simply jammed, so I'm trying another approach. Basically adds a funnel to a print of the version which "failed" due to support being off — it did let the pellets overflow nicely!
First version needed support to print as originally designed, so I can only imagine that v2 does too. (Disclaimer: haven't actually printed v2 yet!)

title: Dual fan cooling duct for Flashforge Creator/Replicator dual

description.text: Newer version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1270858 This is based upon MasterFX's design but with some notable changes. Instead of the airflow directed downwards, it is directed across, aimed right at the tip of the nozzles. No supports required for printing. This duct clips securely onto the extruder assembly using no fasteners. The single fan provides for a nice curtain of air flowing across the print. Adding another fan or a larger fan would serve no useful purpose because there is still a significant restriction, the area of the slot is smaller than the area of the fan. These "muffin" fans are designed to move a volume of air, not build up pressure. The much heavier blower type fan is better for building pressure. There are many very cool fan ducts here on Thingiverse. The ones you see that use muffin fans and have tiny openings for the air to come out, while they may work fine, are extremely inefficient. This design is intended to make better use of the muffin fan's abilities.

title: DJI Phantom Quadcopter Nexus S 4G Holder

description.text:
Needed: 1x 3/16th bolt and accompanying wing nut.  
Using two Sprint phones running on WIMAX and using Skype, this little adapter makes for a rather cool toy.

DISCLAIMER: If your phone ends up flying off into oblivion, don't get mad at me. This can be a very bad idea. I recently gained access to a DJI Phantom Quadcopter, and have been having a lot of fun with it. After seeing some of the offerings for POV equipment and their insane prices, I figured there has to be a cheaper way. Using two Android phones and Skype downloaded on both, connect the phones on a video call, slide into the holder and let someone watching enjoy the craziness of flying in seemingly first person point of view. Use forward facing camera to wave or make lewd gestures at complete strangers as they watch you fly your quadcopter! Can be printed and used to have phone capture video as well, but that doesn't seem as fun to me. I printed two of the phone holders, and sandwiched them around the DJI phantom base. Then using a 3/16th diameter bolt with wing nut tightened to assure firm grip. This base and the phone holder attached are compatible with the 'arms' on another thing of mine (found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34566). However it shouldn't be necessary. The holes measure 18mm apart (from center) and are 5mm in diameter if you would like to make your own phone holder. Simply measure your phones exterior dimensions and copy a similar design to mine. There are two 'bases' attached to this, the DJIPhantomBase has been tested, and held up a 15 minute test flight. The 'DJIPhantomBaseRotating' is a remix that was thought up after, but has yet to be tested. It should be more sturdy, though. The phone holders were printed at 20% infill, and the base was printed at 50% infill.

comments.text: you are a risk taker man
comments.author: Jaymaica

comments.text: Cool mount,  but you can buy a 5.8 vtx with camera for about $70  google TX5805  and a receiver for about the same amount.  that just might be cheaper than crashing a perfectly good phone-in-flight.?  Just saying.
comments.author: Bophoto

comments.text: I have no doubt that this is a TERRIBLE idea for most, this was more of spur of the moment idea to see how well Skype would work for POV, as well as a way to get POV without much in the way of equipment. The risk is high, but the cost has already been incurred.

Hi all, I purchased some magnetic arms for my Mini-Kossel from Ultibots. I have updated the parts to use many different kinds of balls and configurations. See the history below. ( http://www.ultibots.com/magball-arms-balls-215mm/ )
Their carriage design did not work for the liner slides I have. So I made my own. I use the standard 400mm slides. (if there is such a thing as "standard" on a reprap printer) I used 100% infill. I know that for most parts that is just crazy stupid. However, The strength of critical components is paramount. The forces on the part in constant flux. Also, part stiffness is a big factor in print quality. Having issues with this part. Drop me a line. I will do my best to help. All 4 screws are M3 x 16mm. McMaster Carr part no 92095A184 Updated: Aug 4rd, 2017
Add 48mm Ball spacing to all Ball models. Updated: Aug 3rd, 2017
Add 50mm Ball spacing to all Ball models. UPDATED: DECEMBER 9th, 2016
I added a ver that will use the 10mm M4 Tapped ball bearings you usually see on eBay. UPDATED: DECEMBER 1, 2016
Added step files for each model. UPDATED: SEPTEMBER 14, 2006
With this design, you will lose about 10mm off your build plate radius. 20mm of each axis. To fix that problem a new carriage design has been implemented. It can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1769818. UPDATED: May 6 2016
Add a hole to add M3 screw at the top for end stop adjustment. It is sized for an M3 tap. Drill it out with a 2.5mm drill bit. Then tap by hand. If you use a drill with the tap go slow. Cut the plastic don't melt it. Also, added a 40mm ball spacing. Now there is 40, 43, and 45mm spacing. And for both type Ball studs (for Ulitbot arms) and for the 9.5mm sphere with an M3 tapped hole. UPDATED: Feb14 2016
Added files for use with 9.5mm(3/8in) ball bearing with a tapped hole for an M3 screw. Both have 43mm and 45mm ball spacing. UPDATED: Feb13 2016
Add same part but will 45mm Ball spacing UPDATED:
Improved part strength due to improved geometry.
Reduced distance between ball centers to 43mm
Improved belt fit and insertion force when assembling.

description.text:
[UPDATE] 14/01/16 | battery_holder_with_wings_xt60.stl
I have since added an XT60 connector holder so you can now not only store the balance connector but the XT60 connector as well. [UPDATE] 14/01/16 | battery_holder_with_wings.stl
Updated the last version by making it smaller so it will fit snug around the battery as well as adding a small "wing" to slid over the fatshark headband, This eliminates almost all the plastic from touching your head making it an even slimmer fit than the version before. This also mean that you will not have to slide the plastic holder over the headband it can simply be slid in with the battery. [UPDATE] 13/01/15 | battery_holder_V2.stl
I made the walls thinner making it more comfortable as well as making the fillers on the inner and outer corners to make it for fitting on the battery. also I have added some slots on the sides to make it lighter. I have made some changes to the balance connector "plug" making the walls thinner again and reducing the height making it a slimmer fit. [Original Post] 11/01/16 | battery_holder.slt
This is a basic battery "clip" that slids over the battery to stop it from falling out due to the shape unlike the standard Fatshark battery being like a dog bone. It also has a "plug" to hold the balance connector so it will stay out that. it is kinda bulky and I will try to refine it more so keep checking back. Battery is a 1300mAh 3S 25~50C Turnigy nano-tech supplied with a XT60 connector how ever I have made a small adapter from the 2.1mm barrel connector to the XT60 you can also buy these but just as cheap to make (centre of the 2.1mm barrel jack is POSITIVE + out side is NEGATIVE -) Battery Link: https://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=25212

You know those little mechanical claws for grabbing things from far away? Have you ever wanted one that is ten feet long? Now you can make one!

In addition to the printed plastic parts, you'll need:
  • a length of 3/4" metal electrical conduit
  • thin string (twice the length of the conduit)
  • two #4-40 x 3/4" machine screws with nuts (Home Depot)
  • hot glue
  • rubber bands
    • Instructions:

  • Print out all the parts. The claws and guides are easy and don't require support. The handle and base will require support, and were printed successfully in the default orientations in the STL files. You'll want to print the claw pair, base, and handle once, and then print anywhere from 2 to 5 guides depending on how long your conduit is.

  • Put together the claw and the base with the screws, and then shove it on one end of the conduit.

  • Tie one end of the string to one of the claw pieces as shown in the pictures. Glue the knot to the claw to prevent it from slipping off.

  • Put the guides onto the conduit.

  • Take the loose end of the string and run it through the small channels in the guides to the end of the conduit opposite the claw.

  • Take the handle and the loose end of the string and run the string through the channel in the handle. Loop it around the two holes at the end of the handle (the string should go outside of the handle, and then back in), and run the string back through the channel. Put the handle on the conduit, and verify that it can easily slide up and down the conduit.

  • Feed the loose end of the string back through the guides and up to the claw assembly.

  • Glue the guides in place on the conduit, ensuring that the string can move freely through the guide channels. The top guide should be 4 inches from the bottom of the claw. The bottom guide should be 6 inches from the bottom of the conduit. The middle guides should be spaced evenly in between.

  • Pull the loose end of the string so that the handle is up against the bottom guide and the string is taut. Tie the string to the other claw so that it remains taut, and glue it in place.

  • Test the mechanism. The claw should be fully closed when the handle is up against the bottom guide, and should open as you pull the handle away from the claw.

  • Put one or more rubber bands on the claw as shown in the pictures. The claw should snap shut when you're not pulling the handle to open it.

  • Have fun... doing whatever you do with a ten foot long claw grabber?

description.text:
Fan recreation, I own no rights to this...
My first attempt at Kylo Ren's Command Shuttle from Star Wars Episode VII The Force Awakens. Since I didn't see one on this site already, I designed this in Tinkercad using the MetalEarth laser-etched model for reference measurements at 2X scale. Each wing is 2 pieces since the design is different on each side. The wings are at a fixed angle, not hinged or movable like in the movie, hoping to add this later on. The center part needed supports on my printer due to the angles and the overhang of the nose of the ship. For the guns print that file 4 times and glue each pair together. Some assembly and super glue required. Enjoy! Edit: if you want the wings to move checkout this awesome remix here:

To cut down on fish mess I feed my fish every 48 hours.  I keep mainly guppies and a big PlatCat.  Scummy, the PlatCat, gets rather upset when I forget his chips every other day.  And I keep forgetting if I fed them last night or not.  
This project is a resettable timer.  It's green when the fish are happy, yellow when they are getting hungry, red when they must be fed.  Simply press the reset button on the arduino to restart the process.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple White

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Print any arduino case that allows access to the pins. I used Arduino Leonardo Case
by pghauff, published Mar 10, 2014 and bodged in a reset button. I chose the leonardo due to the simplicity of powering the thing with an old cell android phone charger. Assemble the simple 4 part circuit. Insert into Arduino. The .SCH is the Eagle 7.5 schematic also shown as a graphic for simplicity. Due to the Thingiverse interface, you need to hit the arrow button to see the whole image.
The .INO is the Arduino 1.6.7 sketch which you can get the compiler at arduino.cc.

Assembly 1) Insert Arduino into printed case.
2) Insert positive (long) leads from Red into 13, Yellow in 11, Green into 9.
3) Solder and clip all the negative (short) leads together.
4) Solder a 330ohm resistor to the negatives and plug this into GND next to pin 13.
5) Upload the sketch.
6) Provide power.
7) Enjoy
Through desperation and need.

comments.text: I'm happy to report that Scummy is now getting his meals more regularly since installing the FishTiner.

Lightweight hinge for connecting two 2020 aluminum extrusions. Designed to fit within the 20mm corner cube. It isn't designed to be load bearing, but should be strong enough to hold the extrusions its attached to. I would try 910 Nylon if you need it to support more weight. There are multiple angles, but I've only tested the 100° version. Print two matching pieces to make a connector. Parts:
3 - M5x20 Countersunk Socket Screw - the ones that screw into the ends of the tapped aluminum extrusion can be much shorter
2 - M5 Washers - these are inserted from the outside
1 - M5 Locknut - it's easier to tighten if you put the nylon side inside
3 - 8mmx1mm Spacers
2 - 5x10x4 Bearings* - the stack of bearings and spacers goes inside Printer:
-- Eustathios Filaments: (full list can be found on thrinter)
-- Atomic Filament Transparent Orange PLA *affiliate link

title: UFO - sliced model easy to print

description.text:
This is a nice UFO model inspired by the S.H.A.D.O. series (I love!): you can print it in all the scales you like. You just have to print the single slice 9 times to create the complete disc.
The file "UFO.stl" has 6 support blades you can easily remove after printing, you don't need automatic supports or else. If you have a DELTA 20 cm base diam. you could print the model 4 times bigger, obtaining the model you see in the pictures (55 cm diam). After that, you can print the rest: the alien pilot is my own creation made with Sculptrix free modeling software.
This model as been created to decore the ITALYmaker Lab in Milan, hanging it from the floor with an invisible nylon wire.

After that, you can print the rest: the alien pilot is my own creation made with Sculptrix free modeling software. <strong><font color="Orange">Overview & Background:</font></strong>
The technology called, Stereolithography exists since the 80s.
It allow you to design anything with a monomer polymerization, by deposition of successive layers.
It's at the origin of our FDM printers, developed it's been 20 years.
The STL file format was developed for stereolithography. Why are we fascinated by this technology?
Because we are witnesses and participants of an industrial revolution.
A total change in the economic paradigm that has developed during the 19 and 20 th century.
We become craftsmen, designers, and take in hand our evolution. Why am I talking about that?
I think it's a good introduction to show you a perfect demonstration of what we expect from this technology. Design and answer to their own needs.
The proposed application lets you quickly create a case whose use will be defined by the user, the shape and dimensions will be those you have identified and not that the industry proposes / imposes. <strong><font color="Orange">Objective:</font></strong>
The student will have two objectives with a project like this one:
  • Create an application that will be used for future projects , and definitively avoid buying boxes not always appropriate to the needs .

  • Learn programming by a quasi - recreational way , since entirely graphic and visual .

  • Many other knowledge can be transmitted based on the desire of the teacher to deepen a particular aspect of the design .
    • <strong><font color="Orange">Audience</font></strong>
    I'm not familiar with the foreign school grades,
    in France, it's around 10/12 years old they begin to learn programming.
    So, it can be a nice starting way and support project to learn visually to code. The presented project was made in two times,
    I did the box in the first time,
    then I dug more, for the Panel Maker. Like I said in the begining, I was, myself, learning how OpenScad works,
    that will be the same for the students, learning and creating something more complex lesson after lesson. A perfect way to evaluate the level reached. As an assessment <strong><font color="Orange">Skill learned</font></strong>
  • Programmation
  • 3D design
  • 3D printing
    • <strong><font color="Orange">Duration:</font></strong>
    A project like this can be the string to follow throughout all the school year.

Hi Heartman,
Thanks for your work, It's excellent.
I found a minor bug in ventilation part. when we set Vent=1, the exported STL has some problems, specially the Slic3r cannot open the file.
One solution is to change "1" to "Thick/2+0.1" in translate sentence of ventilation code, and the result will like below:
translate([10+i,-Dec_Thick+Dec_size,Thick/2+0.1]){
cube([Vent_width,Dec_Thick,Height/4]);
}
translate([(Length-10) - i,-Dec_Thick+Dec_size,Thick/2+0.1]){
cube([Vent_width,Dec_Thick,Height/4]);
}
translate([(Length-10) - i,Width-Dec_size,Thick/2+0.1]){
cube([Vent_width,Dec_Thick,Height/4]);
}
translate([10+i,Width-Dec_size,Thick/2+0.1]){
cube([Vent_width,Dec_Thick,Height/4]);
}

@Heartman,
Just wanted to follow-up. We may want to have a library of "panel openings". I had modified your original scad to punch openings for chinese rocker switches (with LEDs). They take a few lines of code to add several notches for clips and alignment. I am now seeing lots of folks adding other openings. One way might be to have a list of "includable" openings and you could check for a parameter and include if true. I don't know how the customizer works but it seems that using https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/Include_Statement might be just the ticket. Maybe the thingiverse people can help with the capability so people could contribute to a "hole library". It would awesome to have holes mapped to specific parts! For example, rotary potentiometers have the little alignment hole that is tough to get right! I would be happy to help if additional hands would be useful.

author: dombaud

description.text: This is a modified version of my old Reuleaux Triangle design. Instead of screws it uses snap fitting pieces to hold the 3 layers together. Therefore it is a completely lazzzorcut design :) The "screwlessness" was inspired by the "Screwless Cube Gears" by emmett http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10483

Cut the releaux_triangle_snap_export_final.dxf file. The other file also includes help lines which are handy to have if you want to change the design but you don't want them to get cut.
The design consists of 3 layers:
I used 2mm Delrin for the middle layer (the one with the Reuleaux triangle) because it feels nicer, but acrylic would probably work too except for the small snap fitting pieces which will probably break if you cut it from acrylic. 
The top and the bottom layer are identical and I normaly cut it from 2mm transparent acrylic.
Snap fit together like shown in the picture and have fun while rotating it in the square :)

comments.text: I like the finishing on these :)  I am making a set myself,  did you use the cold acetone vapor? Or did you heat it up .. Whatever details you can provide on the finishing would be awesome
comments.author: rabidninjawombat

comments.text: I heated the acetone on my buildplate at 80°C. Before putting the pieces in the vapor, let everything heat up a little for about 10min. until you see condensed acetone on the walls of your container. When the vapor has reached the top of your container, put in the pieces and let them sit there for about 10 to 15 minutes. You might get varying results depending on the temperature of your pieces. The colder they are, the more condensation you get on the surface. Additionally i placed the pieces on small pre-heated aluminum plates. This prevented the acetone from condensing around the base and thus forming a small acetone lake. You can see the setup in one of the pictures. Good luck!
comments.author: rabidninjawombat

comments.text: I have tried printing one of these pieces at various skin & densities but at some point in the print the extruder head hits one of the spires and it breaks off from the base.  Is these some setting I can try to see if I can prevent that from happening.  The last attempt used a 100% density setting.
comments.author: ajgarvey

comments.text: The overhang on the top of the spiral tends to warp up, then in some occasions one of the spires breaks off when the extruder runs into it. Maybe try to minimize the warping by switching off the layer-cooling fans or reduce the extruder's travel speed so that a warped up overhang has some time to melt uppon impact. Another idea would be to use some other slicer or different slicing settings so that the extruder's path doesn't tend to run into the spires from the warped up side. I used cura 14 and had only two broken spires out of all the pieces. Printed in ABS with 30% infill, 0.1 mm layer height and scaled to 87%. Good Luck!
comments.author: ajgarvey

title: Belt Protector for Wanhao Duplicator i3

description.text:
If you are reading this, you probably have a Wanhao, and if you do, you know that the belt rubs on the bearing blocks. I am getting ready to do some very large prints and wanted to fix this before my project. This is an elegant solution for this problem. I saw another complex design using ball bearings to address this problem, but I was never able to find it again.This design was printed in abs.
I had some ball bearings from another project, 10mm outer diameter, 3mm inner diameter and some M3 screws and thought, why not? UPDATE
The original belt protector left the ball bearing off center. V2 will help with that or you can simply go dual bearings like I did. As suggested, I uploaded a simple roller as substitute for the bearing in case you can't get them. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1251748 It has been found....

Things you will need:
  • Ball bearings, 10mm OD, 3mm ID x2
  • M3 screws x2
  • Printed part x2
  • Hot glue
    • After you print the parts, use the M3 screws to tap the holes that are 2.7mm in diameter. Then screw the ball bearing to the printed part.
    The part should fit perfectly in the holes behind the bearing blocks, pushing the belt slightly down. Add a dab of hot glue for a secured part.

author: JustinSDK

title: custom extruder mount for reprappro mono mendel

description.text:
I found that when I printed anything taller than about 100mm my bowden tube and the wires wrapped around it would rub against the upper frame rods. this custom mount raises the extuder drive higher and rotates it 90 degrees so that the extruder motor sits above the left hand Z motor, the bowden tube and wires now run between the upper frame M8 rods and doesnt rub.
this also allows me to reach maximum hight :)

I printed mine in ABS at 0.3mm layers with 3 shells and 40% infill
the holes may need clearing out to fit fit to upper frame using 4 M3 x 20mm bolts and nuts
washers optional
fit extruder to mount using 2 M3 x 25mm bolts and nuts sorry no pics yet, my camera is having a bad day

comments.text: This bracket is very sturdy.  If I was to re-print it, I'd edit out about 1/3 to 1/2 of the clamp width.  I'd then make the diagonal bracket smaller or hollow with bulkhead reinforcement.  I like the bracket, it just took too much plastic.  Oh, and the extruder motor rests on the left z motor (which may or may not bother you).
comments.author: EdB1

comments.text:
thanks for the feedback. I agree it's a little bulky but that's partly because I was using cheap ABS at the time and didn't want any flex. The extruder motor on mine is about 3mm above the left z stepper motor which I'm comfortable with.
Feel free to modify as you wish, I'd be interested in the resaults

UPDATE: A New updated version of MendelMax is available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20355. It is recommended for all new builds. MendelMax is a new RepRap 3d printer designed by Maxbots. It is a true reprap, using printed brackets, but instead of using threaded rod for the structural elements it uses inexpensive aluminum extrusions. This gives a huge increase in rigidity for a minimal extra cost (Self sourcing will cost about $50 more than a standard Prusa when purchased from the recommended suppliers). The required extrusions are available world wide from a variety of suppliers. In addition to greatly increased rigidity, this design is faster to assemble (probably 4 hours for most users), easier to print, has a larger build volume (~215x235x190 if built at the standard dimensions), and is easier to hack on. Update 2/7/2012: MendelMax full kits and hardware only kits are now available from Maxbots (aka Kludgineer on Thingiverse) @ http://store.mendelmax.com!
For full assembly instructions and parts lists, see http://www.mendelmax.com. The X & Y axes are standard Prusa parts, so any design can be used. UPDATE Update: Update 1/15/2012: Update 2/7/2012:

comments.text: You may be right, I did some reading today and I cannot tell one way or the other whether these are designed to minimize backlash. There are a variety of ways to eliminate backlash in a system, so the fact that they are designed for linear motion does not inherently mean they are designed to minimize backlash. It seems to me that if that were a design feature, ther would say so, but you never know for sure. I have a call in to SDP's engineering department, so hopefully they can confirm one way or the other.

comments.text: How does Mendelmax's greater rigidity translate to vibration? Does vibration propagate from the extruder moving around to the frame?
comments.author: bsg

comments.text: The frame itself does not seem to conduct vibrations badly. Since the extrusions are connected together by plastic, the vibrations tend to be deadened, and the extruder is mounted on the same rods and X ends as on the Prusa, so not a lot of vibration is transmitted to the frame itself.
comments.author: bsg

comments.text: For the table vibration, you might consider mounting some rubber (via adhesive) to the underside of the table.
comments.author: kludgineer

comments.text: That is basically exactly what the silicone heater is. Add to that the layer of insulation below it and the vibration-deadening wooden frame in my kits and there is very little remaining vibration in the table
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Brilliant design again. Just looking at it the printable pieces.... are they printable on a Cupcake?
comments.author: msmollin

comments.text: A cupcake-printable Y Rod Mount is now available in out GitHib repository at https://github.com/maxbots/MendelMax/blob/master/build/YRodMount.stlhttps://github.com/maxbots/Men...
comments.author: msmollin

comments.text: Most pieces are easily printable on a Cupcake, but a few are not. Currently the Top_Vertex_X and Y_Rod_Mount parts are larger than the build area of the Cupcake. You could probably get by without the Top_Vertex piece long enough to print them on the MendelMax (the motor mounts serve the same purpose, these just add rigidity). It would be easy enough to make a smaller version of the Y Rod Mounts that could be printed on the Cupcake, but that would make the rods closer together, so you would lose some rigidity, but again, this should work fine long enough to print the correct part on the MendelMax. I will try to put up a Cupcake printable version of that part sometime in the next few days.
comments.author: msmollin

comments.text: Why not give more vertical clearance for the extruder by moving the vertical frame all the way to the outside and making the bottom horizontal frame sections the same length as the top ones? This is a problem with the Mendel frames that limits the vertical build height to well below the 140 mm spec unless you use the original extruder and hot end design.
comments.author: brnrd

comments.text: I am not 100% certain exactly what you mean, but this design nearly doubles the usable Z axis to about 200mm including the extruder (compared to ~100mm including the extruder on a Prusa, final usable clearance TBD).
comments.author: brnrd

comments.text: I was referring to the triangular frame sections. In the Mendel (both Sells and Prusa), either the extruder motor or gear hits them well below the 140 mm spec. You can move them outside and keep the z smooth and threaded rods in the same location so that the x axis doesn't change.
comments.author: kludgineer

comments.text: BTW, http://mendelmax.com/tikiwiki/tiki-index.php?page=Scalinghttp://mendelmax.com/tikiwiki/... has details on scaling the MendelMax design, so if you really need more Z axis it is easy to add it.
comments.author: brnrd

comments.text: Sorry for the slow response. This is actually not a bad idea, though I don't think I will roll it into the official design. It would add to the cost, and only be beneficial in a few edge cases. This design already gives roughly double the Z and greater Y, so for most prints if you are really pushing the limits you can just rotate it so the long part is in the Y axis.
comments.author: brnrd

comments.author: Mike77

comments.text: If you want to make a printable printer, you would probably be much better off starting from scratch. These extrusions are so nice because of the natural rigidity of the aluminum. switching to plastic extrusions-- even if they were actually extruded in the proper shape and not printed-- would lose most of that benefit. You can certainly print segments that may be useful for accessories and such, but it is doubtful that you will ever be satisfied with  the extrusions as the main structural components.
comments.author: Mike77
